title: 111_hr1943
content: The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" is the short title of this Act. It includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates. The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, where the rate table is further adjusted based on minimum and maximum dollar amounts for each rate bracket. The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, where the rate table is further adjusted based on minimum and maximum dollar amounts for each rate bracket. The tax amounts are adjusted by multipliers based on the statistical area of the individual's primary residence, with rounding to the nearest multiple of $50 if necessary. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 incorporates regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with rate brackets reflecting these adjustments. The Secretary determines multipliers for each statistical area of the United States annually, rounding any amount not a multiple of $50 to the nearest multiple. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 includes cost-of-living adjustments in income tax rates based on statistical areas. Multipliers are determined annually for each area, with specific criteria for different percentage differentials. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 includes cost-of-living adjustments in income tax rates based on statistical areas. Multipliers are determined annually for each area, with specific criteria for different percentage differentials. The cost-of-living index for each statistical area is determined by the Secretary of Labor based on average market prices for the area for the 12-month period ending on August 31 of the calendar year. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 includes cost-of-living adjustments in income tax rates based on statistical areas. Multipliers are determined annually for each area, with specific criteria for different percentage differentials. The cost-of-living index for each statistical area is determined by the Secretary of Labor based on average market prices. The statistical area includes metropolitan statistical areas defined by the Secretary of Commerce and portions of states not within a metropolitan statistical area. The area applicable multiplier for any area outside the United States is 1. The amendment made by the Tax Equity Act of 2009 applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. A transition rule is in place for prescribing multipliers for taxable years in 2010.
